description: From Latin irrīsiō, from irrīdēre, present active infinitive of irrīdeō (“I laugh at”); ir- (“in”) + rīdeō (“I laugh”): compare French irrision.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The act of laughing at another; derision.
examples: From thence he was carried back to Jerusalem, first to Annas, then to Caiaphas, and (as late as it was) then he was examined and buffeted, and delivered over to the custody of those officers from whom he received all those irrisions  […]
